content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Input description a bit vague, but input example makes it clear enought,
Not sure if solvable in 5 minutes, but in 10 minutes it shall be done.
Hello, I quite like your puzzle, hope it will be approved soon

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I really enjoyed this puzzle, especially for Clash of Code. This was perfect. I really hope this gets approved! Good luck!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good enough , its just too long , it took me around 4 minutes to understand the question because of so much data but then it was solvable in 2-3 minutes

Goal
* Please simplify the Goal section, keeping the statement concise and focused. This is especially important for a clash of code, as a short, clear description helps player solve the clash faster. Avoid unnecessary story elements, or complex words (especially for non-native English speakers).

Input
* Next H lines: Consider revising the description to make it clearer and easier to follow:

<<Next [[H]] lines>>: A [[W]]-character string denoting a line of the island. Only these characters are used:
• {{O}} = landing spot (starting point)
• {{X}} = Treasure of Cortés (target)
• {{o}} = land
• {{x}} = fake treasure

* Please change "Line H+2" to "Next line".

* Please format "step(s)" like this: {{step}}({{s}}).

Constraints
* If you use the revised wording above, the second map constraint can be removed.

* Given the second instruction constraint is there, [[steps]] < [[W]], [[H]] may be omitted. In fact, some cases violate this part of the inequality. (I think your original intention was to compare horizontal and vertical steps separately with [[W]] and [[H]]. By the way, the cases where [[W]] = 1 or [[H]] = 1 also violate the constraint.) In turn, the first input ranges constraint may be changed to 1 ≤ [[W]], [[H]], [[steps]] ≤ 30 instead.

* Please remove the first instruction constraint to avoid repetition.

* Consider dropping the third instruction constraint; it's helpful but not critical.

Stub generator / input
* Please read my separate comment in your discussion with @shazman below.

Thanks.

The idea for this puzzle is good, but the starter code needs work. Right now it has placeholder prints and unused imports that should be removed. The input format is read wrong because each instruction has three parts like “1 step South,” but the script only tries to read two, so it breaks. You need to read the number, skip “step(s),” and then take the direction. A loop should be added to find the starting O on the map, use a dictionary for directions, and move step by step instead of skipping the count. The outputs should match the rules: “Chase after them!” if the crew lands on X, “Find the real treasure!” if they land on x, or “They’ll be back.” otherwise. The puzzle idea itself is fun and has a nice theme, but fixing the starter code will make it smoother and less confusing for people who try it.

Hi, thanks for trying my clash! Just to clarify:

- The placeholder prints were intentionally left there so that clashers can copy-paste the respective output lines wherever necessary. It helps save time on Fastest/Reverse mode :)

- Unfortunately, there's nothing I can do about the unused imports. The stub generator is the one responsible for importing the libraries and this is standardised across all clashes / puzzles.

- You mention that the script only tries to read two of the three parts and hence it breaks. May I know where the breakage occurs, and in which language? I've tested the stub generator by simply running the code without editing it, and it fails due to the multiple lines of output but doesn't actually break (throw an error). Same for skipping the "step(s)"; the stub generator should handle that already.

- The starting O on the map is always at (0, 0) - this is listed in the constraints section :)

- May I know what you mean by "move step by step instead of skipping the count"? Could you also let me know how a dictionary for directions could be useful for you here? I'm not quite sure I follow.

- The outputs SHOULD match the rules. Are there any test cases that do not? Also note that the crew has to *end up* at the exact location after following *all* of the instructions step by step - this is in the output section :)

My apologies if any of this is unclear; do let me know what the issues are for you and I'll try my best to fix them!
Thank you for the feedback. I've reworded the problem description and tweaked the constraints and stub generator accordingly.
Thank you for your feedback :)
Thank you :) I hope it will be approved too

Thanks for following up! The breakage happens in Python if you parse "3 steps South" with n, direction = input().split(), since the split has 3 tokens and throws a ValueError; grabbing the last token as the direction avoids it.

The main issue I ran into is in Python when parsing lines like "3 steps South"—a natural first attempt is n, direction = input().split(), but since that produces three tokens it throws a ValueError; using the last token as the direction fixes it, and that’s what I meant by the code “breaking,” while my other points were just quality-of-life suggestions to make the starter clearer and easier for new players.

Thanks for clarifying! I see the confusion now.

The way that the starter code is generated on CodinGame is through their in-built stub generator, which is essentially a very high-level keyword parser that tries to convert keywords into language-specific syntax. Unfortunately, what this means is that us puzzle creators have little control over the way that the starter code is generated. And yes, I don't love it (you can see that my solution doesn't use it at all). But I guess it wasn't meant to cater to specific languages.

What I tried to do in the stub generator is to specifically label the middle "step(s)" portion of each instruction as "Ignore". What this looks like in the stub generator:

for i in range(s):
    inputs = input().split()
    steps = int(inputs[0])
    ignore = inputs[1]
    direction = inputs[2]

Unfortunately, this is the most verbose way of labelling the inputs that I can think of, given the limitations of the stub generator. (I can't even capitalize the ignore variable...) .

Regarding your previous comment on using a dictionary for directions, I would say that's one way of doing things :) The main reasons for not using a dictionary are:

- The stub generator has no functionality for generating dictionaries :( Again, language-specific features are not supported.

- Using a dictionary the way you did reminds me of more advanced algorithms involving 2D matrix traversal; e.g., BFS / DFS. This clash is not meant to be complicated, and I didn't want to give off that idea :)

- In terms of speed, hardcoding each of the 4 known directions (exhaustive) is much faster :)

But of course, there is nothing wrong with your approach. Feel free to experiment!

Ah, that makes sense thanks for explaining how the stub generator works. I hadn’t realized the "ignore" label was already intentional; I see now that the breakage I mentioned is more about how new players might try parsing it in Python (with just two variables) and hit the ValueError. Maybe a quick clarifying comment in the statement or stub itself could help guide them toward the inputs[2] approach so it’s less confusing.

Thanks for clarifying! I hadn’t realized how much the stub generator limits what you can do that makes sense now. The main issue I ran into is in Python when parsing lines like "3 steps South": a natural first attempt is n, direction = input().split(), which throws a ValueError since there are actually three tokens. Using inputs[2] works fine, so maybe a quick clarifying comment could help newer Python players avoid that confusion.

And regarding the dictionary point I wasn’t suggesting it as a requirement, more just as a readability/QoL thing for Python since it keeps direction handling tidy. Totally fair to keep the stub minimal and hardcode the directions though, especially given the clash’s simplicity.

No worries, it is rather unintuitive.

I have added more verbose comments to the statement in the stub generator. (I can't even control where the comments appear in the starter code...). Hopefully it's clearer now.

Awesome, thanks for adding that! I think the extra comments will definitely help make it clearer for new players. And just to say again  I really like the theme of this puzzle, it’s a fun one to play through :)
Thank you, appreciate the support :)

@shazman, I could understand your confusion. You already know you can do:

n, direction = input().split()

(which fails in the current clash), and actually you can also do:

n, _, direction = input().split()

to safely ignore the middle word without a ValueError.

@User123, the intention behind the stub generator is to make parsing as painless as possible, so that players can focus on solving the core task. That said, splitting the instruction into three variables and explicitly naming one `ignore` feels like it goes a little too far.

Two possible alternatives to simplify this:

1. Remove "step(s)" from the input: then there's no need for an `ignore` variable at all, and the hints in the stub may be simplified as well.

2. Keep the instruction as a single string, and let players decide how to parse it themselves.

Hope this helps.
